# Introduction

Let‚Äôs talk about four major players in the health insurance world: UnitedHealth (UNH), CVS Health/Aetna (CVS), Humana (HUM), and Elevance Health (ELV), and how they communicate during earnings calls. If you‚Äôve ever listened to one of these calls, you know they‚Äôre full of buzzwords and corporate-speak, but sometimes, they also reveal a lot about what‚Äôs really happening behind the scenes. By analyzing these companies‚Äô earnings calls from late 2024 through early 2025, we can see clear differences in how they handle tough questions and how that might reflect their overall stability.

## The Evasion Olympics: Who Dodged Best?

First, let‚Äôs break down the numbers. Across 12 earnings calls (3 for each company), management teams were pressed on critical issues like Medicare Advantage (MA) trends, investment spending, and Medicaid profitability. The results? Some dodged better than others.

| Company                  | Evasive Responses (Total) | Dominant Tactic                        | Most-Avoided Topic                     |
|--------------------------|---------------------------|----------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| **UnitedHealth (UNH)**   | 23                        | Philosophical deflection               | Medicare Advantage cost trends         |
| **CVS Health (CVS)**     | 18                        | Panel-style answers with no numbers    | MA trends and PDR sizing               |
| **Humana (HUM)**         | 15                        | Explicit refusal to quantify numbers   | Investment dollar amounts and Stars impact |
| **Elevance Health (ELV)**| 12                        | ‚ÄúPrudence‚Äù mantra and re-baselining    | Medicaid margin recovery timing        |

UnitedHealth took the crown for evasiveness, with 23 instances of dodging direct answers, followed by CVS at 18. Humana and Elevance were a bit more forthcoming, but still not paragons of clarity.

## UnitedHealth: Masters of "Context Over Content"

If there's one thing UNH excels at, it‚Äôs turning a simple question into a philosophical lecture. CEO Andrew Witty is the king of the multi-minute ‚Äúcontext preamble,‚Äù often passing the buck to his deputies‚Äîwho also dodge the original question.

For example, when asked about headwinds to Medicare Advantage trends, Witty responded with:

> ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to ask John to go deeper ‚Ä¶ but first let me **context this a little bit**‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre in an unusual situation... we won‚Äôt pull back from investment‚Ä¶‚Äù

Translation? No actual numbers, just a lot of fluff about strategy and investment. This tactic leaves analysts guessing and investors nervous. It‚Äôs no wonder UNH‚Äôs evasiveness peaked in Q1 2025, coinciding with their acknowledgment of worsening cost trends.

## CVS Health: The Shotgun Approach

CVS is a bit different. They rely on a ‚Äúshotgun panel‚Äù strategy where multiple executives chime in but no one actually answers the question. It‚Äôs like a corporate game of hot potato, everyone talks, but the numbers never materialize.

Take this gem from Q4 2024, when analysts pressed for Medicare Advantage trend details:

> ‚ÄúLet me answer what I can‚Ä¶ **it‚Äôs too early to comment with any confidence**‚Ä¶ we‚Äôd like more data before we get too far ahead of ourselves.‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Tom Cowhey, CVS CFO

In plain English: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not telling you.‚Äù This tactic was consistent across all their calls, making CVS one of the least transparent companies in the group.

## Humana: The Art of Saying Nothing

Humana‚Äôs CEO, Jim Rechtin, takes a slightly different approach‚Äîflat-out refusing to provide numbers. When asked about their 2025 investment spend, he said:

> ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not putting a specific number on it‚Ä¶ we don‚Äôt have a precise number today.‚Äù

This kind of vagueness frustrates analysts, especially when it‚Äôs repeated over multiple calls. By Q1 2025, Humana‚Äôs evasion had plateaued, but their refusal to quantify investments or margin impacts raised plenty of red flags.

## Elevance Health: A Breath of Fresh Air?

Among the four, Elevance Health stands out for its relatively transparent approach. CFO Mark Kaye was notably more forthcoming, often providing actual numbers or detailed explanations. For example, in Q1 2025, he projected mid-single-digit attrition for ACA members:

> ‚ÄúWe do project membership attrition in the mid-single-digit percent range in early Q2.‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Mark Kaye, ELV CFO

This level of detail was refreshing compared to the obfuscation from UNH, CVS, and HUM. It‚Äôs no surprise that Elevance had the lowest number of evasive responses (12) and improved transparency over time.

## What Does This Mean for Investors?

So, what‚Äôs the takeaway here? Evasive communication isn‚Äôt just annoying, it often signals deeper problems. For example:

- **UnitedHealth‚Äôs evasiveness** spiked alongside worsening Medicare Advantage trends. The more they dodged, the more worried analysts became.
- **CVS‚Äôs consistent lack of clarity** hints at systemic instability. If they can‚Äôt even answer basic questions, what else are they hiding?
- **Humana‚Äôs refusal to quantify investments** left investors in the dark about their 2025 strategy, raising doubts about their long-term outlook.
- **Elevance‚Äôs transparency**, on the other hand, suggests confidence and operational stability. They‚Äôre the clear winners when it comes to investor communication.

## The Bigger Picture: Why Transparency Matters

At the end of the day, these earnings calls aren‚Äôt just PR exercises, they‚Äôre a window into how companies handle pressure. The more evasive the answers, the higher the likelihood of underlying issues. Investors should pay close attention to these patterns because they often foreshadow stock performance. For example:

- Companies with heavy evasions, like UNH and CVS, tend to face greater skepticism and volatility.
- Firms that embrace transparency, like Elevance, are more likely to earn investor trust and maintain stability.

## Final Thoughts

In the world of health insurance, transparency is key. While all four companies used some level of evasion during their earnings calls, the degree and style of their deflections varied widely. UnitedHealth and CVS raised the most red flags, while Elevance stood out as a beacon of clarity. For investors, this analysis underscores an important lesson: when management starts dodging questions, it‚Äôs time to dig deeper‚Äîor maybe look elsewhere.

## In-Depth Analysis

### UnitedHealth ‚Äì ‚ÄúContext Over Content‚Äù

**Pattern:** Andrew Witty routinely consumes two-plus minutes ‚Äúsetting context‚Äù before handing the question to three deputies‚Äînone of whom supply the number originally requested.

*Example of gross avoidance*

> ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to ask John to go deeper ‚Ä¶ but first let me **context this a little bit**‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre in an unusual situation‚Ä¶ we won‚Äôt pull back from investment‚Ä¶‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Andrew Witty, **UNH Q3 2024**

**Why it matters:** Analysts asked for a simple sizing of headwinds versus the traditional 13-16 % EPS growth; they received philosophy, not math.  This occurred again in Q1 2025 when Tim Noel admitted to a ‚Äú2x‚Äù spike in utilization but refused to quantify resulting MLR pressure, instead predicting it would ‚Äúpersist into 2026.‚Äù  Shareholders were left extrapolating worst-case scenarios.

### CVS Health / Aetna ‚Äì ‚ÄúThree-Handed Answers‚Äù

**Pattern:** David Joyner introduces the answer, then punts to Steve Nelson for narrative and finally to Tom Cowhey for caveats‚Äîyet Cowhey withholds the requested metric.

> ‚ÄúLet me answer what I can‚Ä¶ **it‚Äôs too early to comment with any confidence**‚Ä¶ we‚Äôd like more data before we get too far ahead of ourselves.‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Tom Cowhey, **CVS Q4 2024**

Analysts repeatedly pressed for exact MA trend (‚ÄúWhat did the trend look like coming out of the year?‚Äù).  Management provided qualitative descriptors (‚Äúmodest‚Äù, ‚Äústubbornly high‚Äù) but **never released the baseline percentage**.

### Humana ‚Äì ‚ÄúFloor, But No Ceiling‚Äù

**Pattern:** CEO Jim Rechtin offers ‚Äúat least a floor‚Äù while refusing to bound the ceiling.

> ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not putting a specific number on it‚Ä¶ we don‚Äôt have a precise number today.‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Jim Rechtin, **HUM Q3 2024**

Humana‚Äôs avoidance is most acute around the ‚Äúfew hundred million‚Äù incremental investments.  Despite three consecutive calls, management would not specify buckets or duration‚Äîvital because those dollars offset EPS growth.

### Elevance Health ‚Äì ‚ÄúPrudent, Premature, Placeholder‚Äù

**Pattern:** CFO Mark Kaye labels virtually every unknown as ‚Äúprudent‚Äù to avoid quantification.

> ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to take time before that‚Äôs fully reflected in rate schedules.‚Äù

Even when asked directly if the Medicaid book is profitable, he answered:

> ‚ÄúIt is expected to be profitable this year, albeit below our target‚Ä¶ you can‚Äôt look at Medicaid in any particular single quarter.‚Äù  
> ‚Äî Mark Kaye, **ELV Q3 2024**

Investors received no numeric margin range, only reassurance of future improvement.
